description: Redevelopment of 23-55 North Street, including the retention of the part built structure to provide a mixed use development comprising a 6-16 storey building, 98 residential units (Use Class C3), 766sqm of flexible uses at ground floor including retail (A1-A4), offices(B1a) and community uses(D1), also associated basement car parking, cycle parking, storage and servicing.
decision_conditions: The proposed development by reason of its poor quality of detailed design would result in an incongruous character and appearance that is harmful to views in and out of the conservation area, detract from the urban grain and visual amenity of the area; and would therefore fail to preserve or enhance the character and appearance of the Romford Conservation Area contrary to policies CP17 (Design), CP18 (Heritage), DC61(Urban Design), DC68 (Conservation Area) of the Adopted Development Plan Documents (2008); Policies 3.5 (Quality and design of housing developments), 7.4 (Local character), 7.5 (Public realm), 7.6 (Architecture) and 7.8 (Heritage assets and archaeology) of the London Plan (2016); and Chapters 15 and 16 of the National Planning Policy Framework (2019).

The proposed development, in the absence of a Section 106 Legal Agreement securing affordable housing contributions, would fail to comply with policy DC6 (Affordable Housing) of the Adopted Development Plan Documents (2008); and Policies 3.10 (Definition of Affordable Housing), 3.11 (Affordable Housing Targets), 3.12 (Negotiating Affordable Housing On Individual Private Residential and Mixed Use Schemes), 3.13 (Affordable Housing Thresholds) and 3.15 Policy 3.15 (Co-Ordination of Housing Development and Investment) of the London Plan (2016).

The proposed development, in the absence of a Section 106 Legal Agreement securing education contributions of £384,000, would fail to comply with policy DC29 (Educational Premises) of the Adopted Development Plan Documents (2008); and Policies 3.18 (Education Facilities) and 3.16 (Protection and enhancement of social infrastructure) of the London Plan (2016).

The proposed development, in the absence of a Section 106 Legal Agreement securing carbon offset contributions of £60,000 would fail to comply with policies DC50 (Renewable Energy) and DC49 (Sustainable Design And Construction) of the Adopted Development Plan Documents (2008); and Policy 5.2 (Minimising carbon dioxide emissions) of the London Plan (2016).

The proposed development, in the absence of a Section 106 Legal Agreement securing active transport contributions of £115,000 would fail to comply with policy DC32 (The Road Network) of the Adopted Development Plan Documents (2008); and Policy 3.16 (Protection and enhancement of social infrastructure) of the London Plan (2016).

The proposed development, in the absence of a Section 106 Legal Agreement securing traffic management contributions of £10,000, would fail to comply with policy CP9 (Reducing the Need to Travel), CP10 (Sustainable Transport) and DC32 (The Road Network) of the Adopted Development Plan Documents (2008); Policy 3.16 (Protection and enhancement of social infrastructure) of the London Plan (2016).

The proposed development, in the absence of a Section 106 Legal Agreement securing on street cycle parking contributions of £15,000 would fail to comply with policy DC35 (Cycling) of the Adopted Development Plan Documents (2008); and Policy 6.9 (Cycling) of the London Plan (2016).

In the absence of a Section 106 Legal Agreement securing the development as 'car free' development would fail to comply with policy DC33 (Car Parking) of the Adopted Development Plan Documents (2008); and Policy 6.13 (Parking) of the London Plan (2016).

Statement Required by Article 35 (2) of the Town and Country Planning (Development Management Procedure) (England) Order 2015: Consideration was given to seeking amendments, but given conflict with adopted planning policy, notification of intended refusal and the reasons for it were given to both the applicant and agent.

The proposed development by reason of its poor quality of detailed design would result in an incongruous character and appearance that is harmful to views in and out of the conservation area, detract from the urban grain and visual amenity of the area; and would therefore fail to preserve or enhance the character and appearance of the Romford Conservation Area contrary to policies CP17 (Design), CP18 (Heritage), DC61(Urban Design), DC68 (Conservation Area) of the Adopted Development Plan Documents (2008); Policies 3.5 (Quality and design of housing developments), 7.4 (Local character), 7.5 (Public realm), 7.6 (Architecture) and 7.8 (Heritage assets and archaeology) of the London Plan (2016); and Chapters 15 and 16 of the National Planning Policy Framework (2019).
